title: In chapter 7. How do I calculate means test line 25 taxes. Trustee says my # is to high b/c I will be adding dependents next yr
question: Basically, I listed the amount taken from my paycheck on average including Federal income, State income, social security tax. The trustee told me to go to the IRS website and recalculate because I am adding dependents for next year. How would that take into account social security and state tax, etc.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Bankruptcy petition,341 meeting of creditors,Bankruptcy documents,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Social security,Tax law,Representing yourself
answers:
If this was a pro se filing (i.e. - you do not have an attorney), I would go talk to one soon.

In *my* estimation, the trustee is overstepping the authority of form B22A to determine abuse. Again, this is based on my experience, your mileage may vary.

However, what happens in the future is, for the most part, irrelevant in a normal Chapter 7 filing. What matters, in all things Chapter 7, is the state of finances on the date of filing of the petition; not, as the Trustee would suggest, what may be in the future. Another argument is - while your deductions may decrease due to another dependent, your other expenses increase for the same reason. If the determination of abuse is based on all known data, and it's known you will be able to deduct less next year, than you should also have the ability to add expenses and dependents known at the time of filing.

All of that said, however, you need to talk to an experienced BK attorney in your area and figure out what will work best in your situation and with this particular Trustee.

Good luck.

The trustee's position is nonsense. The means test is an average of the last six completed months, and does not have a formal line for "IRS Clairvoyance Deductions."**

**Nevertheless, I encountered a similar clairvoyant issue in a recent challenging Ch. 7 Bky in MO, where I practice.
At the 341 meeting of creditors, the UST atty questioned my client on his "failure" to note a change of anticipated revenue/expenses in line #56, suggesting that this line should be used as the twin of the last line of Sch. I, Income, anticipated changes.

I surmise that a mandate has gone out from the EOUST, to enforce this approach in possible 707 abuse situations.

I complied, but your situation seems different.

You need to have your (an) accountant make that determination. What is taken out of your paycheck is irrelevant. You may be over or under-withholding, and it may not even be the same amount for the income received for the relevant 6-month period.

The social security tax shold reman the same regardless of your exemptions. You would need to recalculate state and federal taxes if making these changes are appropriate. You should discuss this issue with your attorney and you may want to have a tax professional calculate the appropriate deductions for you.
